entries.title: US tech giants announces mass layoffs in 2025: From Amazon to Meta here is the complete list of top companies
entries.snippet: In 2025, major US tech companies, including Amazon, Microsoft, Meta, Intel, and others, are enacting large-scale layoffs, impacting tens of thousands of employees. These layoffs are part of a broader effort to boost efficiency through artificial intelligence (AI) integration and cost-cutting. Intel is cutting 15-20% of its Foundry division, affecting over 10,000 workers. Meta has laid off over 21,000 employees since 2022 and continues performance-related cuts. Microsoft underwent its third round of reductions in January, offering no severance and terminating benefits immediately. Amazon's CEO foresees AI eventually replacing some white-collar jobs, suggesting a gradual workforce reduction. Jack Dorsey's fintech firm Block is eliminating around 1,000 positions, while cybersecurity firm Crowdstrike is laying off 5% of its staff (approximately 500 employees) due to AI-driven streamlining. These decisions underscore a significant recalibration in tech industry priorities, with companies investing heavily in AI and realigning their workforce strategies accordingly.

entries.title: Ukraine fighting 10,000 Russian troops in Kursk region, Ukrainian commander says
entries.snippet: Ukraine's top military commander, Oleksandr Syrskyi, reported that Ukrainian forces are engaging around 10,000 Russian troops in Russia’s Kursk region. Ukraine currently controls approximately 90 square kilometers in this area as a preemptive measure to deter Russian attacks. This operation has tied down Russian units that could have been deployed to the Donetsk region, one of the most contested areas in the ongoing conflict. The frontline stretches about 1,200 kilometers and remains intensely contested, with Russia making gains, albeit with significant casualties. Meanwhile, Russia continues to target Ukrainian cities with drone and missile strikes, prompting Ukraine to enhance its air defense systems. Ukraine claims an 82% interception rate of Russian Shahed-type drones, though it still seeks more advanced missile defense systems. The Ukrainian air force is also investing in light aircraft and drone interceptors. Ukraine has focused on striking economic and military infrastructure within Russia, inflicting over $1.3 billion in direct damages and at least $9.5 billion in indirect losses between January and May. The extent to which these figures include damages from operations like "Spider's Web," which targeted Russian warplanes, remains unclear.

entries.title: Russia advances to east-central Ukrainian region amid row over dead soldiers
entries.snippet:
Russian forces have advanced to the edge of Ukraine’s Dnipropetrovsk region, intensifying the conflict despite continuing discussions about peace. Moscow now controls nearly one-fifth of Ukrainian territory, having recently captured over 190 square km in the Sumy region. Russia's 90th Tank Division is attacking from the Donetsk region, threatening Dnipropetrovsk, a region home to over 3 million people before the war. Ukraine is actively defending key positions, including the city of Kostyantynivka.

Tensions are heightened by accusations over peace negotiation sincerity and the handling of war dead. Russia blames Ukraine for stalling the exchange of prisoners and the return of 12,000 bodies, claims Kyiv denies. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy criticized Russia for politicizing humanitarian issues and reaffirmed Ukraine's commitment to prisoner exchanges.

Amid ongoing attacks, including Ukrainian strikes on Russian strategic bombers and rail systems, Russian President Vladimir Putin questioned Ukraine’s willingness for peace and emphasized Moscow's demand for recognition of annexed territories. With the United States warning of a potential significant Russian counterstrike, fears of further escalation loom, making the conflict the most intense in Europe since World War II.

entries.title: G7 summit on wildfire watch for Trumpian explosions in Canada
entries.snippet: At the 2025 G7 summit in Kananaskis, Canada, Prime Minister Mark Carney aims to address pressing global and environmental issues, including Canada's devastating wildfire season, with over 225 active fires and 120 out of control. To foster cooperation, Carney proposed a wildfire charter focusing on equipment interoperability among G7 nations. However, Carney also faces the complex challenge of managing potential disruptions from U.S. President Donald Trump, whose previous G7 appearance ended in controversy and disunity. To prevent a repeat, Carney is keeping the summit's agenda deliberately uncontroversial, focusing on topics like mineral supply chains, energy security, internet disinformation, and WTO reform—areas less likely to provoke Trump's ire. Bilateral talks will handle the more contentious trade issues. Despite these efforts, concerns persist that Trump’s unpredictable behavior may derail the summit. His penchant for drama and social media outbursts could overshadow the substantive discussions. Ultimately, Carney seeks to maintain coherence and unity among G7 members amidst global turmoil and the volatile presence of Trump.

entries.title: More people using mental health resources without a genuine need
entries.snippet: Australia's mental health care system is in crisis, having failed to provide adequate services to those with severe mental illnesses, despite early hopes following the deinstitutionalisation of the 1990s. While awareness of mental health issues has improved and access to care for mild conditions like anxiety and depression has increased, this primarily benefits urban, financially secure individuals. Meanwhile, people with severe illnesses such as schizophrenia and bipolar disorder face worsening conditions, limited access to critical care, inadequate housing, and increased risk of incarceration and early death. Public psychiatric services have deteriorated, offering minimal intervention outside acute care, and many professionals face moral injury due to systemic failures. Despite the National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS) receiving $48 billion annually, only $4 billion is allocated to mental health, with much support directed toward cases of questionable need, such as overdiagnosed developmental conditions in children. Solutions include rebuilding and expanding state mental health systems, shifting to community-based, multidisciplinary care models, reforming the NDIS to cover genuine mental disabilities, and fostering community initiatives like Zimbabwe’s Friendship Bench. Professor Patrick McGorry emphasizes the urgent need for truth-telling, reform, and community-driven advocacy to address these failings and support those most in need.

entries.title: To fix the national debt crisis, Republicans need to raise taxes
entries.snippet: A collection of opinions emphasizes that America's growing national debt and deficits cannot be addressed solely through spending cuts; significant revenue increases are necessary. Commentators highlight that mandatory federal spending comprises two-thirds of the budget, leaving little room for effective cuts without touching entitlements. Many argue that reverting taxes on the wealthy to Eisenhower-era levels or ending excessive tax breaks is essential to fiscal stability. They critique President Trump's proposed tax cuts, which the Congressional Budget Office estimates would add $2.4 trillion to the deficit, while his administration plans to shrink the IRS, reducing its capability to close the $606 billion net tax gap. Critics also oppose relying on regressive tariffs, which disproportionately impact lower-income Americans, as a replacement for progressive income taxes. Additional suggestions include implementing an AI tax on companies profiting from workforce reductions due to automation to fund social welfare and retraining. Overall, the consensus is that Republicans must recognize the revenue problem and raise taxes, particularly on the wealthiest, to maintain government services and ensure economic fairness.

entries.title: Mahmoud Khalil vows to continue protests after release from detention
entries.snippet: Mahmoud Khalil, a Palestinian activist and former Columbia University graduate student, was released after over three months in a federal immigration facility in Louisiana. Khalil, a legal U.S. resident, was not charged with any crimes but was detained for participating in pro-Palestinian protests, which the Trump administration deemed antisemitic and supportive of Hamas. He returned to Newark, New Jersey, welcomed by supporters including Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, who condemned his detention as a First Amendment violation. Khalil vowed to continue protesting against U.S. funding and institutional support of the war in Gaza, denouncing it as genocide. Ocasio-Cortez criticized the Trump administration for suppressing political dissent and pursuing an unlawful legal case. Though released by Judge Michael Farbiarz, who found continued detention unjustified, the government filed an appeal. Khalil also expressed solidarity with other immigrants in detention, asserting that immigration status should not diminish one's humanity.

entries.title: Do you live in a 'lonelygenic environment'? Being in nature may help.
entries.snippet: Loneliness is increasingly recognized as a global public health issue, prompting efforts such as appointing "ministers of loneliness" in the UK and Japan. Research links loneliness to serious health risks, including heart disease and dementia, yet successful interventions remain elusive. Experts now suggest that environmental factors—specifically "lonelygenic environments" dominated by concrete and car-dependency—contribute significantly to social isolation. Urban researchers like Xiaoqi Feng advocate for shifting the focus from individual deficiencies to societal and environmental design. Studies have shown that access to green spaces can reduce loneliness, improve community trust, and encourage social interaction. For example, having 30% green space near one’s home correlated to markedly lower loneliness rates in Australia. Additionally, spending just one to two hours in nature weekly has been associated with reduced feelings of isolation. Initiatives such as "social prescribing," where doctors refer patients to nature-based group activities, are being tested globally through the Recetas project. These interventions aim to use natural environments to foster social connection and improve mental wellness. Researchers emphasize that time spent in nature can lower stress and promote a sense of belonging, suggesting environmental design is a powerful tool in the fight against loneliness.

The article concludes by examining how declining trust in government affects civic engagement and young people's economic participation, such as their willingness to invest or start businesses.

parts:
Below are concrete, very recent data points that illustrate how each pillar of Shapiro’s “Fourth Turning” checklist is already visible on the ground. For each item I highlight just‐published or still-unfolding developments rather than older background trends.

---

### 1  Social breakdown  
* **U.S. street unrest:** Los Angeles erupted on 6 June 2025 after ICE raids; what began as immigration protests escalated into running battles with police and property damage. citeturn0search0  
* **Anti-immigration violence in Europe:** Ballymena, Northern Ireland, saw several nights of rioting in mid-June after far-right activists seized on a criminal case involving Romanian teens. citeturn10search2  
* **Campus flash-points:** The detention of former Columbia graduate student Mahmoud Khalil—and more than 3,000 other arrests tied to Gaza-war protests—shows political dissent on U.S. campuses morphing into prolonged conflict with federal authorities. citeturn8news9  

---

### 2  Civic mistrust  
* **Global survey evidence:** Edelman’s 2025 Trust Barometer puts the world average trust index at 56/100, but the United States languishes in the “distrust” zone at 46—little changed despite the 2024 election cycle. citeturn3view0  
* **National polls:** A May 2024 Pew survey found only **22 %** of Americans trust the federal government to do the right thing “most of the time,” near the lowest reading in six decades of data. citeturn13search6  

---

### 3  World on fire  
* **Middle East escalation:** On 22 June 2025 the U.S. joined Israel in striking Iran’s Fordow, Natanz and Isfahan nuclear facilities, directly widening the Israel–Iran war. citeturn0search3  
* **European war of attrition:** Ukraine reports fighting 10,000 Russian troops inside Russia’s Kursk region while missile and drone attacks pound Ukrainian cities daily—evidence the conflict is expanding rather than winding down. citeturn4news10  
* **Climate disasters:** Canada has already lost **2.6 million ha** to wildfires this year; officials warn 2025 is on track to be the country’s second-worst season on record. citeturn5search3  

---

### 4  Career crisis  
* **AI-driven layoffs:** Amazon, Microsoft, Meta, Intel and others have announced tens of thousands of job cuts in 2025, explicitly linking the reductions to efficiency gains from artificial intelligence. citeturn0news58turn0search5  
* **Worker anxiety spike:** Edelman’s 2025 data show 63 % of employees now fear automation threatens their jobs—up five points in a single year. citeturn3view0  

---

### 5  Meaning crisis  
* **Global isolation:** The WHO’s newly launched *Commission on Social Connection* reports that one-quarter of older adults and up to 15 % of adolescents are socially isolated worldwide. citeturn0search7  
* **U.S. public-health response:** The U.S. Surgeon General’s 2025 strategy frames loneliness as a national epidemic linked to heart disease, dementia and shortened life expectancy, calling for urban design changes to rebuild social ties. citeturn12news10  

---

### 6  Debt crisis  
* **Record sovereign borrowing:** The OECD projects advanced-economy bond issuance will reach **US$ 17 trillion** in 2025—an all-time high—with emerging markets also at peak borrowing levels. citeturn0search8  
* **U.S. fiscal strain:** Interest on the U.S. national debt has jumped 34 % to nearly **US$ 1 trillion** a year, now larger than both defense and Medicare budgets, while total debt tops **US$ 36 trillion**. citeturn7search4  

---

### Synthesis  
These indicators show six feedback loops feeding one another:

* **Low trust** undermines political capacity to manage wars, climate shocks or fiscal tightening.  
* **Wars and climate disasters** divert resources and deepen public fear, amplifying social unrest.  
* **AI-accelerated job disruption** heightens economic insecurity and meaning loss.  
* **Loneliness and mental-health burdens** weaken civic resilience just as societies need cohesion to tackle debt and security emergencies.  
* **Exploding debt service costs** crowd out the very investments (re-skilling, mental-health services, climate adaptation) needed to break the cycle.

In short: the empirical pattern across 2024-25 aligns closely with Strauss & Howe’s “Fourth Turning” stress test. Whether AI “nukes the playing board” or becomes part of a post-crisis rebuild depends on how quickly governments and institutions can restore trust and social capital while navigating simultaneous geopolitical and fiscal fires.

items.title: Mahmoud Khalil vows to continue protests after release from detention
items.snippet: Mahmoud Khalil, a Palestinian activist and former Columbia University graduate student, was released after over three months in a federal immigration facility in Louisiana. Khalil, a legal U.S. resident, was not charged with any crimes but was detained for participating in pro-Palestinian protests, which the Trump administration deemed antisemitic and supportive of Hamas. He returned to Newark, New Jersey, welcomed by supporters including Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, who condemned his detention as a First Amendment violation. Khalil vowed to continue protesting against U.S. funding and institutional support of the war in Gaza, denouncing it as genocide. Ocasio-Cortez criticized the Trump administration for suppressing political dissent and pursuing an unlawful legal case. Though released by Judge Michael Farbiarz, who found continued detention unjustified, the government filed an appeal. Khalil also expressed solidarity with other immigrants in detention, asserting that immigration status should not diminish one's humanity.

items.title: Ukraine fighting 10,000 Russian troops in Kursk region, Ukrainian commander says
items.snippet: Ukraine's top military commander, Oleksandr Syrskyi, reported that Ukrainian forces are engaging around 10,000 Russian troops in Russia’s Kursk region. Ukraine currently controls approximately 90 square kilometers in this area as a preemptive measure to deter Russian attacks. This operation has tied down Russian units that could have been deployed to the Donetsk region, one of the most contested areas in the ongoing conflict. The frontline stretches about 1,200 kilometers and remains intensely contested, with Russia making gains, albeit with significant casualties. Meanwhile, Russia continues to target Ukrainian cities with drone and missile strikes, prompting Ukraine to enhance its air defense systems. Ukraine claims an 82% interception rate of Russian Shahed-type drones, though it still seeks more advanced missile defense systems. The Ukrainian air force is also investing in light aircraft and drone interceptors. Ukraine has focused on striking economic and military infrastructure within Russia, inflicting over $1.3 billion in direct damages and at least $9.5 billion in indirect losses between January and May. The extent to which these figures include damages from operations like "Spider's Web," which targeted Russian warplanes, remains unclear.

items.title: US tech giants announces mass layoffs in 2025: From Amazon to Meta here is the complete list of top companies
items.snippet: In 2025, major US tech companies, including Amazon, Microsoft, Meta, Intel, and others, are enacting large-scale layoffs, impacting tens of thousands of employees. These layoffs are part of a broader effort to boost efficiency through artificial intelligence (AI) integration and cost-cutting. Intel is cutting 15-20% of its Foundry division, affecting over 10,000 workers. Meta has laid off over 21,000 employees since 2022 and continues performance-related cuts. Microsoft underwent its third round of reductions in January, offering no severance and terminating benefits immediately. Amazon's CEO foresees AI eventually replacing some white-collar jobs, suggesting a gradual workforce reduction. Jack Dorsey's fintech firm Block is eliminating around 1,000 positions, while cybersecurity firm Crowdstrike is laying off 5% of its staff (approximately 500 employees) due to AI-driven streamlining. These decisions underscore a significant recalibration in tech industry priorities, with companies investing heavily in AI and realigning their workforce strategies accordingly.
